msIdentifier.repository: Gonville and Caius College, Lower Library
msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 451/392

summary.seg: This composite manuscript contains a large number of medical treatises and recipes. It also includes a unique Middle English deontological text that provides advice to a medical practitioner on their attitude and behaviour towards their patients (pp. 20-22) [transcribed and translated by Ingebretsen (2010)].
The manuscript also includes a small number of (previously unread) charms, one of which contains an unsual invocation of St Frideswide, patron saint of Oxford, against rats.

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: This manuscript comprises five different volumes or parts made of parchment leaves.

foliation.note: Pages [90a-90b] are an unnumbered partial leaf between pp. 90 and 91.

Numbering in black ink in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, superseding medieval foliation in the different parts: 15th-century folio numbers in brown ink in the right-hand upper corners of the rectos for pp. 1-16: '1'-'8'; pp. 67-80: '25'-'31'; and pp. 81-94: '52'-'59' (crossed out or erased) and '40'-'47'.

binding.p: Seventeenth- or eighteenth-century paneled binding with a triple-line fillet border frame and central frame on brown leather over millboards, with plain pastedowns. The classmarks 451 and 392 are printed on labels on the spine.

history.acquisition: In Gonville and Caius College by 1697, when it was recorded as no. 978, together with Gonville and Caius MS 451a/392, in Edward Bernard Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliae et Hiberniae in unum collecti, 2 vols in one (Oxford: Theatro Sheldoniano, 1697). Its printed armorial bookplate with the handwritten classmark numbers '451' (black ink) '392' (red ink) on a paper pastedown on the inside of the upper cover; the classmark '451' written in black ink on p. 1.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry partly draws on M. R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Gonville and Caius College, vol. 2 (Cambridge, 1908), pp. 523-524; and and Kari Anne Rand Schmidt, Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge (Cambridge: Brewer, 2001).

availability.p: Visitors to Gonville and Caius College who wish to consult Lower Library material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Gonville and Caius College: Library Information.

analytic.title: The Twenty-Jordan Series: An Illustrated Middle English Uroscopy Text

'A Leche': A Deontological Text in Gonville and Caius College MS 451/392

analytic.title: Uroscopy in Middle English: A Guide to the Texts and Manuscripts

series.title: Studies in medieval and renaissance history

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 451/392, pp. 1-16

msItem.title: Untitled medical work
msItem.incipit: 1 Duplici causa me cogente socii dulcissimi hoc opus constituere summo opere desideraui
msItem.note:
The text opens with an introduction and list of chapters, followed by a section that begins with the line 'Medicina est sciencia modum' (p. 1: Other copies of what may be the same work can be found in:
Manchester, Chetham's Library, MS 11380
Oxford, Bodleian Libray, MS Bodley 567
Oxford, Bodleian Libray, MS e Musaeo 223, there entitled Compendium Salerni

supportDesc.condition: The text on p. 1 is partially faded and stained. The lower margin of pp. 7-8 has been cut away.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 38-43 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand in Gothic Northern Textualis.

decoNote.p: Two-line and one-line initials in red ink throughout.
One-line capitals highlighted in red ink throughout.

note.p: Title inscription: 'compendium bonum' written in the lower margin of p. 1.
Marginal annotations to and underlining in recipes in brown ink in a 15th-century hand.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 451/392, pp. 17-26

msItem.title: Prologue to an anonymous medical tract
msItem.incipit: 17 Hec ars medicinarum simplicium et compositarum
msItem.note: Prologue only, the remainder of the text has not been copied.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Latin recipes, but including one Middle English recipe
msItem.note: The Middle English recipe occurs on p. 18, and is entitled: 'ad cessandum menstruum'.
Added by one or two hands in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Two recipes against fever
msItem.note: The recipes are 'ffor feueres cotidian and quartan' and 'for þe quartan'.

msItem.title: Tract prescribing a dietary regimen for medical purposes
msItem.textLang: Middle English tract with some Latin
msItem.incipit: 19 It is to vndurstonde þat a diet schal be ȝouun aftir tenour of vertu of þe pacient
msItem.explicit: 19 þe staat niȝ be in ȝouun pauca et subtilis þat is to seie litil and sutil

msItem.title: Two recipes against fevers
Collection of recipes against fevers
msItem.note: Added by one or two hands in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Deontological tract with advice on the deportment and behaviour of a leech
msItem.incipit: 20 [S]enec in þe booc of naturel questiouns seith þer is noon more victorie þan to tame vicis for bi a maner liȝtnes of soule or of bodi vicis quenchen whatsoeuere is of good maner
msItem.explicit: 22 and þe cuntre arise he to comeris go he aȝens noble men bere he felowship to goeris out and whanne hi silf goiþ go he out wiþ licence.
msItem.note: The text cites Seneca and Oribasius.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Added by one or two hands in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: 'Flum Jordan' and 'Longinus miles' charms for staunching blood
msItem.incipit: 26 [H]el[i] sat vppon a courser of bras and bled ffast at his nos [...] And he cried to ihesu crist and said lord god help thi seruand
msItem.note: Added by one or two hands in the late 15th or early 16th century.
The two charms have been thoroughly crossed out.

supportDesc.condition: Creased corners and a few minor tears in some leaves.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 39 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The prologue to a medical tract at the top of p. 17 has been copied by a hand writing in a Gothic cursive script with Anglicana features.

Recipes against fevers and a tract with a dietary regimen on p. 19 and a tract on leeches on pp. 20-22 have been copied by a hand writing in a mixed cursive script but predominantly with Anglicana features.
Additional recipes and charms by several hands writing in Gothic cursive with both Anglicana and Secretary features on pp. 17-18, 19, 22-26.

decoNote.p: One- to three-line initials in brown ink with minor decoration on pp. 17 and 19.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 451/392, pp. 27-48

msItem.title: List of Twenty Colors of Urines [Ten Hot Ten Cold]
msItem.incipit: 27 [I]lke mannes vrine is deuyded in iij partys
msItem.explicit: 44 If þer be humoures in þe ground þei signifie vise of nerys

msItem.title: The Exposition of All Urines and heir Significations
msItem.rubric: 29 [H]ere begynne þe exposicioun of alle vrines and here significaciouns and first of þese þat betoken vndefying and remwes of mateer
msItem.incipit: 27 [U]ryne white and thinne in queche semeth beemes of þe sunne signifie passioun of þe splene
msItem.explicit: 44 þus eendeþ þe declaracion of alle vrines and contentis after ypocras and galyen ye qweche scheweth alle maledye of man explicit discrecio vrinarum
msItem.note: The work is loosely translated or adapted from Walter Agilon's Compendium urinarum; see Tavormina (2014), p. 96 (no. 16.4).

msItem.title: The Declaration of Urines after Isaac and Constantine
msItem.incipit: 45 [H]ere begynneth þe declaracion of þe same after ysak and constantyne þat scheweth þe kynde and þe accidentes and þe cause of þe maledie and queche humour he is gendered
msItem.explicit: 47 and wiþ werk of þe stomak and fulfillyng of þe same ouer mykil werk of þe heed comes oþer while. and oþerwhile comes ouer mykil colde of þe vttereste membris . and of his exces þey make vnfauerable werk in þe bowels

signatures.p: Leaf signatures throughout quire 3: 'aj'-'aviij' and quire 3: 'bj'-'bij', with the other signatures missing because of the cut lower margin of pp. 47-48 and the three missing leaves after p. 48; written with brown ink in the lower right-hand corner.

catchwords.seg: A single catchword in a decorative banderol in the lower margin of p. 40

supportDesc.condition: Water stains throughout, but without rendering the text illegible. The lower margin of pp. 47-48 and three leaves after p. 48 have been cut out

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 32 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written by a single scribe in Anglicana.

decoNote.p: Spaces with guide letters for two-line initials have been left open throughout.

note.p: Notes on urine added by a Secretary hand to the margins of p. 27 and p. 47.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 451/392, pp. 49-80

msItem.title: Tract on Aqua vitae and its uses
msItem.incipit: 49 [A]qua uite prima simplex secunda composita tercia perfectissima
msItem.explicit: 54 and tak þanne a light candel and put it to þe lynen cloth aforn seyd. and as fast þe licour of þe aforseyd pece of lynen cloth is dried. Anon þe flaume of þe fyre in þe aforseyd cloth schal be qwenched. and þe pece of cloth schal be vnbrent.

msItem.title: Tract on the nature and causes of leg ulcers with a recipe against them
msItem.incipit: 54-55 Þis is a soueren medicine and a good passand alle oþere medicines þat j haue herd teld of or ellis of alle oþere þat .j. have proved for to hele a mormal þat it schal nevere breken aȝen
msItem.explicit: 57 and whan þou comest up on þe mormal draw noght þe Rolle ouer faste but whan þou art passed þe mormal drawe þanne as faste as ye lyketh a godis name

msItem.title: The Twenty-Jordan Series [The Twenty Jordans] Karapos version
msItem.incipit: 58 Karapos þe dropisy a wynde vnder þe side þe ston hefdake a postune in þe lunge and a fleume - Colour of þe water as cameles skyn
msItem.explicit: 67 Medicine: Take þe ious of tanse þe rede worte boyle hem in wyn with a litel hony
msItem.note: Uroscopy text with twenty jordans drawn in.
An additional 15th-century note written in a Secretary hand below the text on p. 65 refers to 'Jordanus'.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: One recipe on p. 75 attributed to Thomas de Aston, Canon of Lincoln in 1382: 'Mayster Thomas Asshtoun chanoun of Lincolne'; and another recipe on p. 79 refers to Birstall in the West Riding of Yorkshire: 'ffor I wist and knew a woman in parich of bristall besyde wakefeld in ȝorkschire þer cam oute of here lemes be diuerse times of þise maner wormes'.

supportDesc.condition: The lower margins of pp. 59-62 have been cut off, and pp. 63-64 feature large horizontal cuts.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns (except pp. 58-67 which have two columns). 38-41 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written by a single scribe in an Anglicana script.

decoNote.p: Three- to four-line initials outlined in brown ink with several spaces left blank for initials that were never finished.
Diagrams of 20 urine flasks ('jordan') in brown ink on pp. 58-67, two per page.

additions.note: Marginal additions to the medical texts in different 15th-century hands.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 451/392, pp. 81-94

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes, ointments, oils, and sirups
msItem.note: Collection of more than thirty recipes; some of which have been added by a later 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Unguentum imperiale
msItem.incipit: 86 Vnguentum imperiale is gode for cranyis and brekyng of handys and for kyttinggis etcaetera and sic fit Recipe: perosyn ob gulbani 1 d. turpentini ob olij oliui 1 d. et commisse super lento igne omnia silicet et fit
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the upper margin by a later 15th-century hand.

msItem.title: Two alchemical recipes
Two tracts on the virtues of the herbs vervain and chamomile
msItem.incipit: 89 Verueyne is of two maneres and bothe is of o vertu drynk it in wyn and it helpith
msItem.explicit: 90 if it be leyde þerto in þe maner of a playstre and it lettith þe hefdwerk if it be waschen þerwith þat is to say with þe licour þat it is sothen in
msItem.note: The first tract invokes Plinius.

msItem.title: Charm for driving away rats
msItem.incipit: 90 Sancta Geretrudis sancta Frediswyda et erit scriptum in iiijor partibus domus et fugient omnes ratones
msItem.note: The charm invokes St Gertrude of Nivelles, who was associated with offering protection again mice and rats. No such association appears to exist with St Frideswide, the other saint who is invoked in the charm, but she may have been associated with with Getrude on account of their abbatial positions.
Full transcription; the text has been crossed out.

msItem.title: Medical note
msItem.incipit: 90 Nota þat all swete þingis are hote of kynde and all bytter and soure þingis are cold
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The Middle English recipes are for a white salve and for 'colman', which contains white lead

msItem.title: Two medical recipes
Three medical recipes for the eyes
Collection of medical and cosmetic recipes
msItem.note: The collection includes four recipes for a lighter skin and for removing freckles (faded, but legible under UV light).

supportDesc.condition: Pages [90a-90b] are a fragmentary leaf, more than half of which has been cut off vertically.

layout.seg: Ruled in plummet, frame and line ruling. Single columns. About 46 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Pages 81-90 have been opied by a single scribe in an Anglicana script.
Pages 90-94 have been copied by various cursive hands in Anglicana and Secretary scripts.

decoNote.p: Large (2-3 lines) initials outlined with black ink and coloured in with red or yellow ink.
A human face drawn on the letter 'K' (Kyng) that has been highlighted in red ink in the upper margin of p. 81.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
